Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy vs. Conventional Wound Therapy for Surgical Abdominal Wound Healing Impairment

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to NPWT or conventional wound therapy (CWT) using a computer-generated list with allocation concealment.

Participants.evidence: 539 adult patients with surgical abdominal wound healing impairment (SAWHI) without fascial dehiscence across 34 sites in Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to NPWT or conventional wound therapy (CWT)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was resource use, including inpatient and outpatient time, personnel, and material for wound treatment over 42 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to NPWT or conventional wound therapy (CWT) using a computer-generated list with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 539 adult patients with surgical abdominal wound healing impairment (SAWHI) without fascial dehiscence across 34 sites in Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands from August 2, 2011, to January 31, 2018.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was primarily per-protocol (NPWT 157; CWT 174).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Treatment length was significantly shorter with NPWT [Mean (SD) NPWT 22.8 (13.4) days; CWT 30.6 (13.3) days; P < 0.001].
